raw_text:
Coach Ranieri sacked by Valencia
 
 Claudio Ranieri has been sacked as Valencia coach just eight months after taking charge at the Primera Liga club for the second time in his career.
 
 The decision was taken at a board meeting following the side's surprise elimination from the Uefa Cup. "We understand, and he understands, that the results in the last few weeks have not been the most appropriate," said club president Juan Bautista. Former assistant Antonio Lopez will take over as the new coach. Italian Ranieri took over the Valencia job in June 2004 having been replaced at Chelsea by Jose Mourinho.
 
 Things began well but the Spanish champions extended their winless streak to six after losing to Racing Santander last weekend. That defeat was then followed by a Uefa Cup exit at the hands of Steaua Bucharest. Ranieri first took charge of Valencia in 1997, guiding them to the King's Cup and helping them to qualify for the Champions League. The 54-year-old then moved to Atletico Madrid in 1999, before joining Chelsea the following year.
llama3.2:1b: Claudio Ranieri was sacked as Valencia coach after eight months at the club following their surprise elimination from the Uefa Cup.
Former assistant Antonio Lopez will take over as new coach.

The decision followed a Uefa Cup exit and a six-match winless streak, which included a loss to Racing Santander.
Former assistant Antonio Lopez will take over as new coach.
gemma2:2b: Claudio Ranieri has been sacked as Valencia coach after a string of poor results.
He was replaced by Antonio Lopez, who will take over as the new coach.
Ranieri had previously coached Valencia from 1997 to 1999 and he is now back in the same role for the second time during his career after being let go from Chelsea.

Coach Ranieri sacked by Valencia

Claudio Ranieri has been sacked as Valencia coach just eight months after taking charge at the Primera Liga club for the second time in his career.
The decision was taken at a board meeting following the side's surprise elimination from the Uefa Cup.
"We understand, and he understands, that the results in the last few weeks have not been the most appropriate," said club president Juan Bautista.
Former assistant Antonio Lopez will take over as the new coach.
Italian Ranieri took over the Valencia job in June 2004 having been replaced at Chelsea by Jose Mourinho.
Things began well but the Spanish champions extended their winless streak to six after losing to Racing Santander last weekend.
That defeat was then followed by a Uefa Cup exit at the hands of Steaua Bucharest.

The decision was taken at a board meeting following the side's surprise elimination from the Uefa Cup.

The side lost to Racing Santander last weekend, which was then followed by a Uefa Cup exit at the hands of Steaua Bucharest.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Climbing into second place at Manchester United, Claudio Ranieri took over as Valencia coach on his second trip there following an eight-month tenure.

Having started coaching at the club after being replaced by Mourinho in 2004 and earlier at Manchester United (1997-2000), he has been involved with several clubs, including Atletico Madrid where he transitioned from Chelsea in 1999 to Chelsea again in 2000.
His coaching career led to a six-game winless streak ending with a defeat to Racing Santander and followed by a Uefa Cup exit to Steaua Bucharest.
tinyllama:1.1b: Coach Ranieri was dismissed by Valencia after being forced out of the club just eight months into his second tenure as manager.
The decision was taken following a surprise elimination from the Uefa Cup that left the side with poor results, underscoring the failure of the Italian's first stint in charge.
Former assistant Antonio Lopez will replace him, taking over after the departure of Jose Mourinho at the end of last season.

Despite good results during Ranieri's tenure at Valencia (six wins from six), the team extended their winless streak to six before losing out on the Uefa Cup, and were subsequently eliminated from the competition for the second time in three seasons.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In a shock development, Valencia Coach Claudio Ranieri has been relieved of his duties after being dismissed by the club's board just eight months into his tenure.
The Portuguese manager's sacking comes after the team was eliminated from the Uefa Cup following their surprise elimination from the competition.
Before joining Valencia, Ranieri had a highly successful spell at Chelsea from 2004 to 2008, where he led the Blues to domestic and European cups.
He was appointed as head coach of Valencia in June 2004 and guided the Spanish club to an impressive start with victories over Chelsea and Roma in the UEFA Champions League group stage.
However, that success was not to be replicated on a larger scale, with Valencia having a winless streak since then.
Aside from his impressive footballing career, Ranieri has also held the position of assistant coach for several clubs, including Chelsea and Atletico Madrid.
He joined Valencia in 1997, taking on the role of head coach in 1999 before moving to Atletico in 1999.
The club's board decided to part ways with Ranieri after an unsuccessful period in charge, citing a decline in results under his management.
